title: 107_hr1221
content: The Act is titled the "Community Partners Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2001" and includes a program called the "Community Partners Next Door Program." The "Community Partners Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2001" recognizes the importance of teachers, law enforcement officers, firefighters, and rescue personnel in communities. It offers discounted purchase prices on HUD-owned properties to these public service employees, encouraging and rewarding their dedication. Amendments to the National Housing Act include providing discount and downpayment assistance for teachers. The "Community Partners Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2001" offers a 50 percent discount for teachers and public safety officers purchasing eligible HUD-owned properties. This discount is applicable from fiscal years 2000 through 2004, encouraging these public service employees to invest in properties for their use. The "Community Partners Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2001" provides a 50 percent discount for teachers and public safety officers buying HUD-owned properties. The discount requires the property to be used as the buyer's primary residence for at least 3 years. The property can be sold to a local government or nonprofit organization for resale to a teacher or public safety officer, or directly to a buyer who is a teacher or public safety officer. The "Community Partners Neighborhood Preservation Act of 2001" offers a 50 percent discount on HUD-owned properties for teachers and public safety officers. The purchasing unit of local government or nonprofit organization must pass on the discount to the buyer. The Act offers a 50% discount on HUD-owned properties for teachers and public safety officers. If they purchase a property at a discounted price and finance it with an insured mortgage, the downpayment is $100. Regulations will prevent undue profit from reselling these properties. Definitions for this program are provided. In the context of the Act offering a 50% discount on HUD-owned properties for teachers and public safety officers, the definitions provided include 'elementary school', 'secondary school', 'eligible property', and 'public safety officer'. The Act defines 'teacher' as an individual employed full-time in an elementary or secondary school as a certified classroom teacher or administrator. Amendments are made to Section 204(h) of the National Housing Act. The Secretary must issue regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments made to Section 204(h) of the National Housing Act. The Congress suggests that the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development should collaborate with other federal agencies owning suitable properties for housing to explore including them in programs for law enforcement officers, teachers, or firefighters.
